155312.content:
John Cooper had never worked a day in his life, until that day. His family was rich, he wasn’t even sure from what but money had never been something he had to think about unless he was thinking about how much they had. As long as he was somewhat well behaved and didn’t get anyone pregnant he got everything that he wanted, whenever he wanted it, no questions asked. He had assumed that going to school and taking business classes would be enough to placate his father and keep the checks coming, but a family friend had put it into John’s father’s head that his son needed “real hands on experience in the workforce” if he was someday going to inherit the family’s assets and so John found himself, for the first time in his life, in an office.

His father’s conditions had admittedly been fairly lenient: John just had to work one hour in one of the family’s financial buildings downtown. Something about “building character,” which John had rolled his eyes at. Thanks to his business classes John was technically qualified for this position (though whether or not he’d paid any attention in said classes was another question) but it had quickly become clear he didn’t have the temperament for real work. It had been mildly amusing to dress up in his nice suit and boss around some of the peons (none of them worked for him technically, but they didn’t need to know that) but as he dealt with his third person of the day, his already extremely short fuse was burnt out.

He drummed his fingers on the table irritatedly as he listened to the tearful old woman sitting across from him tell some long story about how she was going to lose her home thanks to the interest rates on the loan the company had given her and how her family had lived there for generations and how she had nowhere else to go and blah blah blah. It was a very sad story that, unfortunately, fell upon deaf ears. Fortunately although John wasn’t exactly the most compassionate guy, he also wasn’t a patient one, and he would do anything to speed up this interaction.

“Ugh… I’m tired of this, just take it.” John said. The old woman looked up at him with wide eyes.

“Excuse me?” She breathed out with a wavering voice. John glanced over at the old woman with barely disguised disdain, nearly sneering at how pathetic she looked. He puffed out his chest and looked down his nose at her.

“This whole thing is taking up way more time than it’s worth, I’ll just get rid of the debt and we can be done with it,” John sighed with exasperation and began pressing keys on the computer before him. “This’ll be easier. Your house is cheap anyways, it’s barely worth it to force you out.”

“You mean after all of this struggle… it’s mine?” Tears began leaking from the old woman’s eyes.

“Calm down lady, it’s just a cheap shack. I could buy twenty of them right now if I wanted to, I think my family can spare one.” He clicked the last box on the form and submitted it, leaning back into the chair and rubbing his fingers over his eyes. He’d only been working for a few minutes and he was already stressed out! When he opened his eyes again he saw the old woman staring at him expectantly. “Are you deaf or something? I said I settled the debt, you can go now. Don’t come back.”

“Oh thank you! Thank you!” She exclaimed as a huge smile broke over her face. “This means the world to me young man, I won’t forget this.”

”This demented old bat will probably forget her on name in a few days.” John thought, but he was preening a little bit at the hint of praise she was offering him so instead he said “Yes, well, I’d say you owe me but as we know you don’t have anything worthwhile.”

The old woman perked up. “Oh, but I do!” She closed her eyes and began mumbling, and John was about to say something rude when he suddenly felt a strange shiver run through his body. The old woman opened her eyes and smiled at him warmly, unfazed by the cold, confused glare she received in return.

“What was that?” He asked. He pulled his suit jacket a little closer to himself but it did nothing to ward off the (not unpleasant) chill than lingered beneath his skin.

“A gift,” she said flatly. “You now have the power to swap anything with anyone just by thinking about it. Traits, body parts, possessions, just think of it and it’s yours to control. It’s the least I can do to thank you for giving me my apartment.”

“I have what?” John asked, stupefied. ”She must really be crazy,” he thought to himself.

“You’re totally crazy,” He said to her. “Leave before I call security.”

“You’ll see…” She whispered, her eyes twinkling knowingly. “Thank you again.”

John was moments away from calling security when the woman finally got up and hobbled out of the room of her own accord. When the door shut behind her and he could hear the click-clack of her cane fading away down the hallway John breathed a sigh of relief. Crinkling up his nose, he reached into one of the drawers and pulled out a can of air freshener, spraying the room to cover up the slightly flower scent of the old woman’s perfume. He’d have to talk to his father about this because John wasn’t going to be able to put up with dealing with the unwashed masses for long. This was why they had employees, to deal with people like that!

He thought about the nonsense she’d been spewing about switching body parts and was about to dismiss them as the ramblings of a senile old woman but… something about it made him pause. He’d definitely felt something when she’d been chanting, and the idea that this could all be real wouldn’t leave his mind. He decided he needed to get out of the office and clear his head. Despite the amount of time left on his “shift” he headed out of the office early; after dealing with that old woman he’d earned it, hadn’t he?

John took off from the office towards campus, unaware of the strange events that would follow.

info.description:
David Reynolds was just an average college student until his life was changed forever when a mysterious old woman grants him the power to swap anything with anyone. The story also includes branches where someone else is granted the power instead.

Gift Points will be given out to good chapters. The amount of points will depend on how good/long your chapters are. Happy writing.

Special thanks to Switcher and engineered for all the wonderful additions.

How the powers work
The person with the power can swap any physical or metal trait as well as clothes and possessions with any person just by thinking about it
They can also choose who is aware of each swap they make
Only equivalent parts can be swapped
Swaps can only be performed on real people within visual range
The powers do not work on people in pictures or on TV, etc.

This story stands on its own, but it is also the sixth part in a series of loosely related interactive stories that share the same universe.

A few quick rules:
1. Please try to use good spelling and grammar
2. Please try to be consistent within a story branch (both in terms of plot consistency and maintaining the 3rd person past tense)
3. Please try to have fun
